quotes.topic_title: Skills-first hiring during early COVID shock
quotes.text: We started seeing in our data is you had some areas like maybe hospitality was really getting hit, but some areas like customer service that just couldn't hire enough.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete supply-demand mismatch that practitioners can look for in their own marketplaces or hiring funnels.

quotes.topic_title: Skills-first hiring during early COVID shock
quotes.text: You'd think the marketplace would balance pretty quickly. You'd think, okay, maybe these people will start moving to other jobs, but it wasn't happening.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that markets don’t automatically rebalance, pointing to hidden friction in matching systems.

quotes.topic_title: Skills-first hiring during early COVID shock
quotes.text: A large reason behind this, people are used to looking for certain particular titles, and they didn't start realizing other people could do this job.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Identifies title-based matching as a root cause of poor mobility—useful for diagnosing why qualified candidates aren’t being considered.

quotes.topic_title: Skills-first hiring during early COVID shock
quotes.text: We made a pretty big push in something we call skills-first hiring.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Names the core methodology LinkedIn used to address the mismatch, offering a clear approach practitioners can adopt.

quotes.topic_title: Skills-first hiring during early COVID shock
quotes.text: This was the idea that we could translate people's experiences into a set of skills, and by that we could help them really start balancing the marketplace with a much different system.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Provides the actionable mechanism—mapping experience to skills—to improve matching and mobility across roles.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: On Twitter, an account called The Curious PM tagged me with a request to have someone from LinkedIn come on the podcast and talk about how they operate and what they've learned about building products that serve so many different types of customers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the core product challenge of designing for many distinct customer types—useful framing for multi-sided or complex platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Hari's been at LinkedIn for eight-and-a-half years and he leads the Talent Solutions Product Team as VP of product, which is also LinkedIn's biggest business, and includes all of the hiring and learning products, which you'll hear about in this episode.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives concrete scope and organizational context (largest business; hiring + learning) for the lens through which the episode’s lessons are drawn.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our chat, Hari shares what he's seeing change in the hiring market, what you can do to improve your odds of finding a job through LinkedIn, what he's learned about building and maintaining really complex systems like LinkedIn, tips for getting into product management, and some lessons from his own course on product management.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A compact list of practitioner-relevant takeaways (job search tactics, complex systems, PM career advice) that signals the actionable themes to listen for.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Plus, we also talk about how LinkedIn has been able to become a real source of valuable content and a lot less cringe over the past couple years, which I've definitely noticed and I share in our chat.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to a notable product/content evolution (quality and tone shift) that can inform strategies for improving community content over time.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best way to see what Miro is all about and how it can help your team collaborate better is not to listen to me talk about it, but to go check it out for yourself.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical reminder to prioritize hands-on evaluation over marketing when assessing tools for team collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Miro is a killer tool for brainstorming with your team, laying out your strategy, sharing user research findings, capturing ideas, giving feedback on wire frames, and generally just collaborating with your colleagues.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete checklist of high-leverage use cases teams can apply immediately to improve cross-functional collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You might be building an incredible AI product, but if you are using the same datasets as your competitors to train your models, you don't have much of an advantage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A competitive mental model for AI product differentiation: proprietary or unique data sources can matter as much as model quality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Brave Search is the fastest-growing search engine since Bing, and it's 100% independent from the big tech companies.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific positioning/data point that can inform build-vs-buy decisions for teams needing an alternative search index provider.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn feed becomes more valuable content
quotes.text: Everything at LinkedIn is a very connected ecosystem. One of the things that we always think about is how the whole system fits together.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A systems-thinking framing for product decisions: optimize the whole ecosystem, not isolated features.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn feed becomes more valuable content
quotes.text: Every time there's a discussion, something I'm really, really proud about working here is, everyone knows how that decision is going to be made. It's all about how we're connecting people to economic opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A clear North Star makes decision-making predictable and aligned across teams, even in complex systems.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn feed becomes more valuable content
quotes.text: "If you think about what a feed is when it connects someone to opportunity, it's got to do a couple of things really, really well."
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Reframes a feed’s purpose around user outcomes (opportunity), which then constrains what “good” looks like.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn feed becomes more valuable content
quotes.text: We've done a ton of member surveys on this, a ton of thought behind it.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Highlights member research (surveys) as a key input to guide feed strategy rather than relying on intuition alone.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn feed becomes more valuable content
quotes.text: We've really, really been focused on driving those two systems. How does someone connect to opportunity both through the people and through the content that they actually want?
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A practical two-part model for feed value: relationships (network) plus knowledge/advice (out-of-network content).

quotes.topic_title: Algorithm, ML, and genAI for knowledge
quotes.text: I think what's happened over time is we've gotten more and more clear with what our members really want, which is this ability to feel close to those relationships and the ability to really get that knowledge that they need.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A practical product lens: improve the feed by sharpening the definition of user value (relationships + knowledge) before tuning algorithms.

quotes.topic_title: Algorithm, ML, and genAI for knowledge
quotes.text: I think one of the beauty of working with that vision of connecting people to opportunity, there is always some piece of friction. There is always something we could be doing better.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A durable operating mindset for complex systems: treat product quality as continuous friction-reduction rather than a finish line.

quotes.topic_title: Algorithm, ML, and genAI for knowledge
quotes.text: But certainly, there's a lot of machine learning and algorithms that go behind these systems. Many of them, as we start understanding that these are things that people get value by, it's about how do we make sure that we're giving people that interesting knowledge?
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Emphasizes that ML ranking improvements follow from clearly identifying what users find valuable (e.g., “interesting knowledge”).

quotes.topic_title: Algorithm, ML, and genAI for knowledge
quotes.text: The other one, which is new, but I'm just particularly excited about, we're starting to do a lot of things which are gen AI-assisted.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Highlights an emerging methodology: using genAI features (not just ranking) to help users contribute and surface expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Algorithm, ML, and genAI for knowledge
quotes.text: If there's anything with knowledge or advice, I think that's what a lot of people are looking for.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Actionable content guidance for creators and teams: knowledge/advice content aligns with what members consistently say they want.

quotes.topic_title: Talent Solutions scope: hiring and learning marketplaces
quotes.text: It's so hard at LinkedIn to separate one product from the other. It's really the way we run. It's the way we think about the product. It's really the way we build.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A core product-building philosophy: treat products as an interdependent system rather than isolated features or teams.

quotes.topic_title: Talent Solutions scope: hiring and learning marketplaces
quotes.text: All of this to me is a very, very connected ecosystem on how those items work together in order to give people opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A mental model for designing cross-surface flywheels (feed ↔ jobs ↔ network ↔ learning) that compound user value.

quotes.topic_title: Talent Solutions scope: hiring and learning marketplaces
quotes.text: We think about it as two different marketplaces. There's a hiring marketplace, which is, how do we connect job seekers and recruiters and hiring managers? And then there's a learning marketplace, which is, how do you connect learners to instructors?
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A clear organizing framework for scoping a complex org/product area around marketplace pairs and their participants.

quotes.topic_title: Talent Solutions scope: hiring and learning marketplaces
quotes.text: Many people don't know this. We actually have two large film studios. We bring in instructors. We film a lot of content. One's in Europe and one's in Santa Barbara.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A concrete example of vertical integration to improve marketplace supply quality (creator/instructor content) at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Talent Solutions scope: hiring and learning marketplaces
quotes.text: Yeah. It's very much the one model that we sometimes use internally as well is, how do we operate as marketplaces inside an ecosystem?
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A memorable internal model: combine marketplace thinking with ecosystem thinking to manage complexity and coordination.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring market shifts: skills and values-based discovery
quotes.text: I actually think some of the changes that occurred during the last couple of years are actually sticking around.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Contrarian take that today’s hiring-market swing doesn’t fully revert the structural shifts introduced in recent years.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring market shifts: skills and values-based discovery
quotes.text: We made a pretty big push in something we call skills-first hiring. This was the idea that we could translate people's experiences into a set of skills, and by that we could help them really start balancing the marketplace with a much different system.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for improving matching: convert experience into skills to enable cross-industry mobility and better marketplace liquidity.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring market shifts: skills and values-based discovery
quotes.text: At this point, roughly 47% of our recruiters will come in, explicitly use skills when they start looking for candidates.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Specific adoption data point indicating skills-based hiring is becoming a mainstream recruiter workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring market shifts: skills and values-based discovery
quotes.text: It's one of the things that I think is so interesting about building products today is, it has to clearly be something people want.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Product principle practitioners can apply: durable change requires aligning with real user demand rather than top-down mandates.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring market shifts: skills and values-based discovery
quotes.text: We also have to be receptive enough to amplify that signal and allow it to work through a system so that it could actually be easy to use.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Actionable product-building guidance: detect user signals and scale them through system design so the behavior becomes effortless.

quotes.topic_title: Open to Work evolution and internal mobility signals
quotes.text: It's been through phases and I think those phases really reflect on the perception of how it's changed.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A useful mental model: product evolution often tracks (and can intentionally shape) shifting user perception over time.

quotes.topic_title: Open to Work evolution and internal mobility signals
quotes.text: In the beginning it was, you could say you're open to work, but it was a secret signal to recruiters if you will.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Shows a pragmatic rollout pattern: start with a low-stakes, private signal before making a socially sensitive feature public.

quotes.topic_title: Open to Work evolution and internal mobility signals
quotes.text: Actually it was around COVID when a lot of the stigmas of unemployment changed dramatically, because everyone started understanding you're in this different situation.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Highlights how external events can rapidly shift social norms, creating a window to expand or reframe a product feature.

quotes.topic_title: Open to Work evolution and internal mobility signals
quotes.text: We're trying to do Open to Internal Work where you can say, "I'm actually at the point where I may want the next play internally in my role," and an internal recruiter can see you.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A concrete example of applying the “signal” concept to internal mobility—making career intent legible to the right audience.

quotes.topic_title: Open to Work evolution and internal mobility signals
quotes.text: As you can imagine, I would actually even maybe argue more stigma about being concerned about upsetting your manager.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Counterintuitive insight: internal job seeking can be more socially risky than external searching, affecting adoption and design choices.

quotes.topic_title: PM hiring trends and job-seeker tactics
quotes.text: But if you look at tech, it's down about 50% year-over-year.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A concrete market-level data point that explains why PM job searches feel unusually hard right now.

quotes.topic_title: PM hiring trends and job-seeker tactics
quotes.text: The first is, in those markets, you do want to make sure that the more you can do to form relationships and say that this is what you can do, which is always helpful.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Direct, actionable guidance to prioritize relationship-building as a lever when hiring markets tighten.

quotes.topic_title: PM hiring trends and job-seeker tactics
quotes.text: Against each skill, you can actually add different kinds of credentials. I would really encourage people to add work products if that's something that they're actually building.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A practical tactic for skills-first hiring: attach proof (work products/credentials) to each listed skill to increase credibility.

quotes.topic_title: PM hiring trends and job-seeker tactics
quotes.text: If you have experience in that industry and you're able to show that you have experience in that industry or some kind of understanding of it, I think that's a way to separate.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A differentiation framework for PM candidates: lean into industry/domain knowledge as a separator when functional PM skills are commoditized.

quotes.topic_title: PM hiring trends and job-seeker tactics
quotes.text: Imagine that you are applying for a PM role, but that particular software is in, I don't know, automotive tech. If you happen to have worked in automotive before, have a knowledge about cars, that's a very helpful way to get in.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A specific example showing how domain familiarity can create an edge even when many candidates have similar PM fundamentals.

quotes.topic_title: Improving recruiter discovery: intent and skills signals
quotes.text: There's two things that anyone who's hiring is always going to look for. They're going to look for your skills and capabilities and they're going to look for your intent and interest in the role.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A simple 2-part framework for optimizing a profile: make both skills and intent legible to recruiters.

quotes.topic_title: Improving recruiter discovery: intent and skills signals
quotes.text: If you're looking for a role, be open about it and tell the companies that you're looking for it. Those are really high signals of intent.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Direct, actionable guidance to explicitly signal job-search intent to improve recruiter discovery.

quotes.topic_title: Improving recruiter discovery: intent and skills signals
quotes.text: The other thing you can do on LinkedIn is you can actually go through when you say open to work and you can specify particular kinds of jobs and things you're looking for. I think that more detailed intent helps make sure you're showing it to the right place.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Tactical advice: specificity in intent improves matching and targeting to the right recruiters/roles.

quotes.topic_title: Improving recruiter discovery: intent and skills signals
quotes.text: In a world where you're looking at skills, you can go through and say, "Look, I can do these things and you could put evidence behind it."
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A shift from title-based proof to skills-plus-evidence as a more accessible way to demonstrate capability.

quotes.topic_title: Improving recruiter discovery: intent and skills signals
quotes.text: Open to work certainly has a high signal to noise.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A data-like claim that “Open to work” is a particularly strong indicator recruiters can rely on.

quotes.topic_title: Senior hiring: recruiting vs job applications
quotes.text: We certainly have CPO jobs that are posted, but the difference often is job posts versus recruiting.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Highlights the key mental model that senior hiring is driven more by outbound recruiting than by inbound applications.

quotes.topic_title: Senior hiring: recruiting vs job applications
quotes.text: More and more senior roles are often recruited.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A concise, actionable takeaway for senior candidates to prioritize being discoverable and networked rather than relying on applying.

quotes.topic_title: Senior hiring: recruiting vs job applications
quotes.text: We find that people will use LinkedIn in order to connect to a CPO and many people who are senior will say, "Oh, I got a message on LinkedIn and that led to this," or they made a long-term recruiting contact.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of how senior opportunities often originate from relationship-building and recruiter outreach on LinkedIn.

quotes.topic_title: Senior hiring: recruiting vs job applications
quotes.text: But it may not happen through you finding a job and hitting the application button.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that the highest-leverage path for senior roles is often indirect—via connections and recruiting—rather than applying.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn culture: North Star and decision clarity
quotes.text: We started from that point and we worked backwards from there in this concept of, "Hey, I do believe that the most important thing is connecting to opportunity and we should really understand how to do that. Let's just start from there."
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A practical “work backwards from the North Star” method for resetting a strategy after feedback or confusion.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn culture: North Star and decision clarity
quotes.text: To me, it was another way of you're in these large systems, you're in these large companies, you're in these large ... I think LinkedIn is very special because no matter what it is, it's got a very good North Star. It was a moment for me to really hammer that home, that as long as you get that North Star ahead of you, you're going to be just fine.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for decision-making in complex orgs: clarity comes from consistently orienting around a single North Star.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn culture: North Star and decision clarity
quotes.text: But if you can understand intent and how this is unblocked and why you want to prioritize that item, all of a sudden the world gets a lot simpler.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A prioritization heuristic: focus on user intent and what unblocks it to simplify tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn culture: North Star and decision clarity
quotes.text: I do think it's a lot of repeat, repeat, repeat. I do think that's it. I do think the culture has a pretty high immune system now in the sense that when you aren't operating by that, people can see it and they operate against it.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: An operational culture mechanism: repetition builds an “immune system” that flags and corrects misaligned decisions.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn culture: North Star and decision clarity
quotes.text: We think a lot about number of hires, converting hires. How many people did we match? Which is a real tangible way of looking at opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Concrete marketplace output metrics that translate a lofty mission into measurable outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern growth team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical gap teams face: experimentation is critical, but tooling often doesn’t fit modern stacks, creating friction and inefficiency.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to waste of time building internal tools or trying to run your own experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable warning about the hidden cost of poor experimentation infrastructure—teams either reinvent tooling or misuse ill-suited systems.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most about working there was our experimentation platform, where I was able to slice and dice data by device types, country, user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of what “good” experimentation enables: fast segmentation across key dimensions to understand impact and heterogeneity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic clickthrough metrics and instead, use your North Star metrics, like activation, retention, subscription, and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical measurement framework: optimize experiments against North Star metrics rather than shallow proxy metrics like clicks.

quotes.topic_title: Building complex ecosystems: second-order effects and governance
quotes.text: You have to think through second and third and maybe even fourth effects and manage that as you go through.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A practical mental model for complex ecosystems: anticipate multi-step downstream consequences, not just first-order impact.

quotes.topic_title: Building complex ecosystems: second-order effects and governance
quotes.text: We've put in things like we have something called RAPID, which is a really easy way to know who the decision-maker is. Just, you line up who's a recommender, who has to agree, who's a decision-maker.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A governance framework to reduce decision ambiguity and unblock cross-team work in interconnected systems.

quotes.topic_title: Building complex ecosystems: second-order effects and governance
quotes.text: It's more of a personal rule, but one thing I love to say is, if you had three back and forths in an email, you got to pick up the phone. And if you've been on the phone for 20 minutes, it's time to just write that decision-maker and go.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: Concrete escalation heuristics that prevent coordination overhead from stalling progress.

quotes.topic_title: Building complex ecosystems: second-order effects and governance
quotes.text: And then a five-day alignment is, you should hold your managers accountable. That in five days if someone has something that they haven't been able to escalate and solve, that's probably then on the next level of person.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A time-boxed management accountability mechanism to keep complex orgs from getting stuck in unresolved dependencies.

quotes.topic_title: Building complex ecosystems: second-order effects and governance
quotes.text: I would argue the most important thing is to have a single name on that decision line, because that usually makes sure that you can get a decision very quickly.
quotes.speaker: Hari Srinivasan
quotes.context: A crisp principle for decision velocity: explicit single-threaded ownership beats consensus in complex ecosystems.
